names: Verbal abuse; a crude substitute for argument; "sticks and stones may break my bones but names can never hurt me"

spec: A detailed description of design criteria for a piece of work
dictum: An opinion voiced by a judge on a point of law not directly bearing on the case in question and therefore not binding
dibs: A claim of rights; "i have dibs on that last slice of pizza"
avowal: A statement asserting the existence or the truth of something
bid: Invoke upon; "wish you a nice evening"; "bid farewell"
alibi: Exonerate by means of an alibi
reply: React verbally; "she didn't want to answer"; "answer the question"; "we answered that we would accept the invitation"
banns: A public announcement of a proposed marriage
caveat: A warning against certain acts; "a caveat against unfair practices"
obit: A notice of someone's death; usually includes a short biography
posit: Put before; "i submit to you that the accused is guilty"
axiom: A saying that is widely accepted on its own merits
fib: Tell a relatively insignificant lie; "fibbing is not acceptable, even if you don't call it lying"
tale: A message that tells the particulars of an act or occurrence or course of events; presented in writing or drama or cinema or as a radio or television program; "his narrative was interesting"; "disney's stories entertain adults as well as children"
flunk: Fail to get a passing grade; "she studied hard but failed nevertheless"; "did i fail the test?"

sally: A military action in which besieged troops burst forth from their position
quip: Make jokes or quips; "the students were gagging during dinner"

gibe: Laugh at with contempt and derision; "the crowd jeered at the speaker"
typo: A mistake in printed matter resulting from mechanical failures of some kind
treaty: A written agreement between two states or sovereigns
pact: A written agreement between two states or sovereigns
satire: Witty language used to convey insults or scorn; "he used sarcasm to upset his opponent"; "irony is wasted on the stupid"; "satire is a sort of glass, wherein beholders do generally discover everybody's face but their own"--jonathan swift
banter: Be silly or tease one another; "after we relaxed, we just kidded around"
jape: A humorous anecdote or remark intended to provoke laughter; "he told a very funny joke"; "he knows a million gags"; "thanks for the laugh"; "he laughed unpleasantly at his own jest"; "even a schoolboy's jape is supposed to have some ascertainable point"

wow: Impress greatly; "the speaker wowed the audience"

pun: Make a play on words; "japanese like to pun--their language is well suited to punning"

lief: In a willing manner; "this was gladly agreed to"; "i would fain do it"

greyly: Having a grey appearance; "lonely creeks are opal in the dawn, sword-blue in the sun, greyly silver under misty moons"
oft: Many times at short intervals; "we often met over a cup of coffee"
haply: By accident; "betrayed by a word haply overheard"
hazily: Through a haze; "we saw the distant hills hazily"
rashly: In a hasty and foolhardy manner; "he fell headlong in love with his cousin"
hotly: In a heated manner; "`to say i am behind the strike is so much nonsense,' declared mr harvey heatedly"; "the children were arguing hotly"
hereof: Of or concerning this; "the twigs hereof are physic"
hereto: To this writing or document; "the charts hereto attached"
oddly: In a strange manner; "a queerly inscribed sheet of paper"
about: (of quantities) imprecise but fairly close to correct; "lasted approximately an hour"; "in just about a minute"; "he's about 30 years old"; "i've had about all i can stand"; "we meet about once a month"; "some forty people came"; "weighs around a hundred pounds"; "roughly $3,000"; "holds 3 gallons, more or less"; "20 or so people were at the party"
icily: In a cold and icy manner; "`mr. powell finds it easier to take it out of mothers, children and sick people than to take on this vast industry,' mr brown commented icily"
idly: In an idle manner; "this is what i always imagined myself doing in the south of france, sitting idly, drinking coffee, watching the people"
lazily: In a slow and lazy manner; "i watched the blue smoke drift lazily away on the still air"
pertly: In an impudent or impertinent manner; "a lean, swarthy fellow was peering through the window, grinning impudently"
per_se: With respect to its inherent nature; "this statement is interesting per se"
indeed: In truth (often tends to intensify); "they said the car would break down and indeed it did"; "it is very cold indeed"; "was indeed grateful"; "indeed, the rain may still come"; "he did so do it!"
keenly: In a keen or penetrating way; "he was keenly aware of his own shortcomings"; "she pitied her sister acutely"; "acutely aware"
lamely: In a weak and unconvincing manner; "`i don't know, edward,' she answered lamely"
laxly: In a permissively lenient manner; "he felt incensed that tarrant should have been treated so leniently given his crime"
lewdly: In a lewd and obscene manner; "he had seen how in their dances the white men and women held one another obscenely"
limply: Without rigidity; "the body was hanging limply from the tree"
meanly: In a nasty ill-tempered manner; "`don't expect me to help you,' he added nastily"
basely: In a despicable, ignoble manner; "this new leader meanly threatens the deepest values of our society"
tidily: In a tidy manner; "the door gave access to a tidily furnished sitting-room where chintz and oak predominated"
sadly: In an unfortunate or deplorable manner; "he was sadly neglected"; "it was woefully inadequate"
again: Anew; "she tried again"; "they rehearsed the scene again"
nearer: (comparative of `near' or `close') within a shorter distance; "come closer, my dear!"; "they drew nearer"; "getting nearer to the true explanation"
nigher: (comparative of `near' or `close') within a shorter distance; "come closer, my dear!"; "they drew nearer"; "getting nearer to the true explanation"
nobly: In a noble manner; "she has behaved nobly"
nohow: In no manner; in no way; "we could nohow make out his handwriting"
numbly: In a numb manner; without feeling; "i stared at him numbly"
nowise: In no manner; "they are nowise different"
palely: In a manner lacking interest or vitality; "a palely entertaining show"
alas: By bad luck; "unfortunately it rained all day"; "alas, i cannot stay"
primly: In a prissy manner; "the new teacher alienates the children by behaving prissily"
thence: From that circumstance or source; "atomic formulas and all compounds thence constructible"- w.v.quine; "a natural conclusion follows thence"; "public interest and a policy deriving therefrom"; "typhus fever results therefrom"
ergo: (used as a sentence connector) therefore or consequently
racily: In a racy manner; "racily vernacular language"
asea: In the direction of the sea; "the sailor looked seaward"
if_not: Perhaps; indicating possibility of being more remarkable (greater or better or sooner) than; "will yield 10% if not more"; "pretty if not actually beautiful"; "let's meet tonight if not sooner"
beyond: On the farther side from the observer; "a pond with a hayfield beyond"
slimly: In a slim or slender manner; "a slenderly built woman"; "slightly built"
smugly: In a smug manner; "the bureaucrats explained smugly that the facts provided by their own experts show no cause for concern"
sorely: In or as if in pain; "she moved painfully forward"; "sorely wounded"
sourly: In a sour manner; "he complained sourly that the new rules only benefitted the managers"
trimly: In a trim manner; "he was trimly attired"
to_it: To that; "with all the appurtenances fitting thereto"
madly: In an insane manner; "she behaved insanely"; "he behaves crazily when he is off his medication"; "the witch cackled madly"; "screaming dementedly"
subtly: In a subtle manner; "late nineteenth-century french opera at its most beautiful, subtly romantic with a twilight melancholy"
tamely: In a tame manner; "the labour movement allowed itself to be run out of power tamely"
by_far: By a considerable margin; "she was by far the smartest student"; "it was far and away the best meal he had ever eaten"
tartly: In a tart manner; "`never mind your immortal soul,' she said tartly"
tautly: In a taut manner; "the rope was tautly stretched"
thinly: Without force or sincere effort; "smiled thinly"
overly: To a degree exceeding normal or proper limits; "too big"
too: In addition; "he has a mercedes, too"
also: In addition; "he has a mercedes, too"
below: On a floor below; "the tenants live downstairs"
unduly: To an undue degree; "she was unduly pessimistic about her future"
verily: In truth; certainly; "i verily think so"; "trust in the lord...and verily thou shalt be fed"- ps 37:3
vilely: In a vile manner; "his vilely spelt and illiterate letters"
wanly: In a weak or pale or languid manner; "she was smiling wanly"
whence: From what place, source, or cause
widely: So as to leave much space or distance between; "widely separated"
yeah: Not only so, but; "i therein do rejoice, yea, and will rejoice"
aloft: At or on or to the masthead or upper rigging of a ship; "climbed aloft to unfurl the sail"
gayly: In a joyous manner; "they shouted happily"
redly: Displaying a red color; "the forge belched redly at the sky"-adria langley
merely: And nothing more; "i was merely asking"; "it is simply a matter of time"; "just a scratch"; "he was only a child"; "hopes that last but a moment"
but: And nothing more; "i was merely asking"; "it is simply a matter of time"; "just a scratch"; "he was only a child"; "hopes that last but a moment"
after: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; "he apologized subsequently"; "he's going to the store but he'll be back here later"; "it didn't happen until afterward"; "two hours after that"
stably: In a stable solid fixed manner; "the boulder was balanced stably at the edge of the canyon"
openly: In an open way; "he openly flaunted his affection for his sister"
so-so: In an acceptable (but not outstanding) manner; "she plays tennis tolerably"
at_all: In the slightest degree or in any respect; "are you at all interested? no, not at all"; "was not in the least unfriendly"
a_lot: To a very great degree or extent; "i feel a lot better"; "we enjoyed ourselves very much"; "she was very much interested"; "this would help a great deal"
before: At or in the front; "i see the lights of a town ahead"; "the road ahead is foggy"; "staring straight ahead"; "we couldn't see over the heads of the people in front"; "with the cross of jesus marching on before"
vastly: To an exceedingly great extent or degree; "he had vastly overestimated his resources"; "was immensely more important to the project as a scientist than as an administrator"
in_all: With everything included or counted; "altogether he earns close to a million dollars"
twice: To double the degree; "she was doubly rewarded"; "his eyes were double bright"
lastly: The item at the end; "last, i'll discuss family values"
ahead: Toward the future; forward in time; "i like to look ahead in imagination to what the future may bring"; "i look forward to seeing you"
along: In line with a length or direction (often followed by `by' or `beside'); "pass the word along"; "ran along beside me"; "cottages along by the river"
alike: Equally; "parents and teachers alike demanded reforms"
aloud: With relatively high volume; "the band played loudly"; "she spoke loudly and angrily"; "he spoke loud enough for those at the back of the room to hear him"; "cried aloud for help"
around: (of quantities) imprecise but fairly close to correct; "lasted approximately an hour"; "in just about a minute"; "he's about 30 years old"; "i've had about all i can stand"; "we meet about once a month"; "some forty people came"; "weighs around a hundred pounds"; "roughly $3,000"; "holds 3 gallons, more or less"; "20 or so people were at the party"
almost: (of actions or states) slightly short of or not quite accomplished; all but; "the job is (just) about done"; "the baby was almost asleep when the alarm sounded"; "we're almost finished"; "the car all but ran her down"; "he nearly fainted"; "talked for nigh onto 2 hours"; "the recording is well-nigh perfect"; "virtually all the parties signed the contract"; "i was near exhausted by the run"; "most everyone agrees"
or_so: (of quantities) imprecise but fairly close to correct; "lasted approximately an hour"; "in just about a minute"; "he's about 30 years old"; "i've had about all i can stand"; "we meet about once a month"; "some forty people came"; "weighs around a hundred pounds"; "roughly $3,000"; "holds 3 gallons, more or less"; "20 or so people were at the party"
mainly: For the most part; "he is mainly interested in butterflies"
forrad: At or to or toward the front; "he faced forward"; "step forward"; "she practiced sewing backward as well as frontward on her new sewing machine"; (`forrad' and `forrard' are dialectal variations)
aback: Having the wind against the forward side of the sails; "the ship came up into the wind with all yards aback"
abeam: At right angles to the length of a ship or airplane
dearly: In a sincere and heartfelt manner; "i would dearly love to know"
infra: (in writing) at a later place; "see below"; "vide infra"
supra: (in writing) at an earlier place; "see above"
partly: To some extent; in some degree; not wholly; "i felt partly to blame"; "he was partially paralyzed"
doubly: In a twofold manner; "he was doubly wrong"
wholly: To a complete degree or to the full or entire extent (`whole' is often used informally for `wholly'); "he was wholly convinced"; "entirely satisfied with the meal"; "it was completely different from what we expected"; "was completely at fault"; "a totally new situation"; "the directions were all wrong"; "it was not altogether her fault"; "an altogether new approach"; "a whole new idea"; "she felt right at home"; "he fell right into the trap"
flatly: In an unqualified manner; "he flatly denied the charges"
ad_lib: Without advance preparation; "he spoke ad lib"
highly: At a high rate or wage; "highly paid workers"
solely: Without any others being included or involved; "was entirely to blame"; "a school devoted entirely to the needs of problem children"; "he works for mr. smith exclusively"; "did it solely for money"; "the burden of proof rests on the prosecution alone"; "a privilege granted only to him"
cosign: Sign jointly; "husband and wife co-signed the lease"
write: Communicate or express by writing; "he wrote about his great love for his wife"
erase: Remove from memory or existence; "the turks erased the armenians in 1915"
delete: Cut or eliminate; "she edited the juiciest scenes"
enter: Set out on (an enterprise or subject of study); "she embarked upon a new career"
log_up: Record a distance travelled; on planes and cars
sum_up: Determine the sum of; "add all the people in this town to those of the neighboring town"
affirm: Establish or strengthen as with new evidence or facts; "his story confirmed my doubts"; "the evidence supports the defendant"
verify: Confirm the truth of; "please verify that the doors are closed"; "verify a claim"
assert: Postulate positively and assertively; "the letter asserts a free society"
avow: Admit openly and bluntly; make no bones about
aver: Report or maintain; "he alleged that he was the victim of a crime"; "he said it was too late to intervene in the war"; "the registrar says that i owe the school money"
depone: Make a deposition; declare under oath
attest: Provide evidence for; stand as proof of; show by one's behavior, attitude, or external attributes; "his high fever attested to his illness"; "the buildings in rome manifest a high level of architectural sophistication"; "this decision demonstrates his sense of fairness"
spew: Eject or send out in large quantities, also metaphorical; "the volcano spews out molten rocks every day"; "the editors of the paper spew out hostile articles about the presidential candidate"
spue: Eject the contents of the stomach through the mouth; "after drinking too much, the students vomited"; "he purged continuously"; "the patient regurgitated the food we gave him last night"
vouch: Give surety or assume responsibility; "i vouch for the quality of my products"
allege: Report or maintain; "he alleged that he was the victim of a crime"; "he said it was too late to intervene in the war"; "the registrar says that i owe the school money"
plead: Offer as an excuse or plea; "she was pleading insanity"
defend: Argue or speak in defense of; "she supported the motion to strike"
assure: Make certain of; "this nest egg will ensure a nice retirement for us"; "preparation will guarantee success!"
fix_up: Find (something or someone) for; "i'll fix you up with a nice girl"
invoke: Request earnestly (something from somebody); ask for aid or protection; "appeal to somebody for help"; "invoke god in times of trouble"
apply: Ask (for something); "he applied for a leave of absence"; "she applied for college"; "apply for a job"
allude: Make a more or less disguised reference to; "he alluded to the problem but did not mention it"
add: Determine the sum of; "add all the people in this town to those of the neighboring town"
append: Add to the very end; "he appended a glossary to his novel where he used an invented language"
opine: Expect, believe, or suppose; "i imagine she earned a lot of money with her new novel"; "i thought to find her in a bad state"; "he didn't think to find her in the kitchen"; "i guess she is angry at me for standing her up"
redden: Make red; "the setting sun reddened the sky"
rename: Name again or anew; "he was renamed minister of the interior"
send: Broadcast over the airwaves, as in radio or television; "we cannot air this x-rated song"
blanch: Cook (vegetables) briefly; "parboil the beans before freezing them"
blench: Turn pale, as if in fear
agree: Be in accord; be in agreement; "we agreed on the terms of the settlement"; "i can't agree with you!"; "i hold with those who say life is sacred"; "both philosophers concord on this point"
blab: Divulge confidential information or secrets; "be careful--his secretary talks"
dally: Consider not very seriously; "he is trifling with her"; "she plays with the thought of moving to tasmania"
coquet: Talk or behave amorously, without serious intentions; "the guys always try to chat up the new secretaries"; "my husband never flirts with other women"
natter: Talk socially without exchanging too much information; "the men were sitting in the cafe and shooting the breeze"
claver: Talk socially without exchanging too much information; "the men were sitting in the cafe and shooting the breeze"
wigwag: Send a signal by waving a flag or a light according to a certain code
behave: Behave well or properly; "the children must learn to behave"
beckon: Appear inviting; "the shop window decorations beckoned"
summon: Call in an official matter, such as to attend court
bruit: Tell or spread rumors; "it was rumored that the next president would be a woman"
sing: Divulge confidential information or secrets; "be careful--his secretary talks"
expel: Force to leave or move out; "he was expelled from his native country"
eject: Leave an aircraft rapidly, using an ejection seat or capsule
sough: Make a murmuring sound; "the water was purling"
yaup: Emit long loud cries; "wail in self-pity"; "howl with sorrow"
wrawl: Cry loudly, as of animals; "the coyotes were howling in the desert"
screak: Make a high-pitched, screeching noise; "the door creaked when i opened it slowly"; "my car engine makes a whining noise"
skreak: Make a high-pitched, screeching noise; "the door creaked when i opened it slowly"; "my car engine makes a whining noise"
emit: Express audibly; utter sounds (not necessarily words); "she let out a big heavy sigh"; "he uttered strange sounds that nobody could understand"
chirk: Make a shrill creaking, squeaking, or noise, as of a door, mouse, or bird
intone: Utter monotonously and repetitively and rhythmically; "the students chanted the same slogan over and over again"
recite: Narrate or give a detailed account of; "tell what happened"; "the father told a story to his child"
churr: Make a vibrant sound, as of some birds
chirr: Make a vibrant noise, of grasshoppers or cicadas
cronk: Utter a hoarse sound, like a raven
siss: Express or utter with a hiss
sizz: Express or utter with a hiss
cackel: Make a cackling sound; "the fire cackled cozily"
soften: Lessen in force or effect; "soften a shock"; "break a fall"
ignore: Bar from attention or consideration; "she dismissed his advances"
convey: (of information) make known; pass on; "she conveyed the message to me"
pin_on: Ascribe blame or guilt for something to (someone); "pin the blame on the innocent man"
deny: Refuse to recognize or acknowledge; "peter denied jesus"
ask: Address a question to and expect an answer from; "ask your teacher about trigonometry"; "the children asked me about their dead grandmother"; "i inquired about their special today"; "he had to ask directions several times"
stet: Printing: cancel, as of a correction or deletion
vie: Compete for something; engage in a contest; measure oneself against others
put_in: To insert between other elements; "she interjected clever remarks"
submit: Refer for judgment or consideration; "the lawyers submitted the material to the court"
go_for: Give an affirmative reply to; respond favorably to; "i cannot accept your invitation"; "i go for this resolution"
oppose: Be resistant to; "the board opposed his motion"
quit: Put an end to a state or an activity; "quit teasing your little brother"
hinder: Hinder or prevent the progress or accomplishment of; "his brother blocked him at every turn"
gird: Put a girdle on or around; "gird your loins"
rearm: Arm again; "after the war, the defeated country was not rearmed by the victors"
re-arm: Arm anew; "after the war, the defeated country was not allowed to rearm"

unarm: Take away the weapons from; render harmless
embed: Fix or set securely or deeply; "he planted a knee in the back of his opponent"; "the dentist implanted a tooth in the gum"
sit: Be around, often idly or without specific purpose; "the object sat in the corner"; "we sat around chatting for another hour"
rotate: Plant or grow in a fixed cyclic order of succession; "we rotate the crops so as to maximize the use of the soil"
enlist: Hire for work or assistance; "engage aid, help, services, or support"
lose: Withdraw, as from reality; "he lost himslef in his music"
chouse: Defeat someone through trickery or deceit
outwit: Beat through cleverness and wit; "i beat the traffic"; "she outfoxed her competitors"
exceed: Be greater in scope or size than some standard; "their loyalty exceeds their national bonds"
outdo: Get the better of; "the goal was to best the competition"

resist: Resist immunologically the introduction of some foreign tissue or organ; "his body rejected the liver of the donor"
fend: Try to manage without help; "the youngsters had to fend for themselves after their parents died"
assail: Attack in speech or writing; "the editors of the left-leaning paper attacked the new house speaker"
set_on: Attack someone physically or emotionally; "the mugger assaulted the woman"; "nightmares assailed him regularly"
harass: Annoy continually or chronically; "he is known to harry his staff when he is overworked"; "this man harasses his female co-workers"
outvie: Be more of a rival than
invade: Occupy in large numbers or live on a host; "the kudzu plant infests much of the south and is spreading to the north"
occupy: Consume all of one's attention or time; "her interest in butterflies absorbs her completely"
beset: Annoy continually or chronically; "he is known to harry his staff when he is overworked"; "this man harasses his female co-workers"
hem_in: Surround in a restrictive manner; "the building was hemmed in by flowers"
repel: Reject outright and bluntly; "she snubbed his proposal"
go_off: Happen in a particular manner; "how did your talk go over?"
crump: Explode heavily or with a loud dull noise
lurk: Lie in wait, lie in ambush, behave in a sneaky and secretive manner
bet_on: Place a bet on; "which horse are you backing?"; "i'm betting on the new horse"
poach: Cook in a simmering liquid; "poached apricots"
strive: Attempt by employing effort; "we endeavor to make our customers happy"
deploy: To distribute systematically or strategically; "the u.s. deploys its weapons in the middle east"
avenge: Take revenge for a perceived wrong; "he wants to avenge the murder of his brother"
retire: Withdraw from circulation or from the market, as of bills, shares, and bonds
ingest: Take up mentally; "he absorbed the knowledge or beliefs of his tribe"
eat_up: Enclose or envelop completely, as if by swallowing; "the huge waves swallowed the small boat and it sank shortly thereafter"
use_up: Require (time or space); "it took three hours to get to work this morning"; "this event occupied a very short time"
eat: Cause to deteriorate due to the action of water, air, or an acid; "the acid corroded the metal"; "the steady dripping of water rusted the metal stopper in the sink"
assign: Decide as to where something belongs in a scheme; "the biologist assigned the mushroom to the proper class"
reuse: Use again after processing; "we must recycle the cardboard boxes"
deaden: Make vapid or deprive of spirit; "deadened wine"
extend: Expand the influence of; "the king extended his rule to the eastern part of the continent"
exert: Make a great effort at a mental or physical task; "exert oneself"
dine: Have supper; eat dinner; "we often dine with friends in this restaurant"
fress: Eat a lot and without restraint
drench: Permeate or impregnate; "the war drenched the country in blood"
imbibe: Receive into the mind and retain; "imbibe ethical principles"
guggle: Flow in an irregular current with a bubbling noise; "babbling brooks"
guzzle: Drink greedily or as if with great thirst; "the boys guzzled the cheap vodka"
lap_up: Take up with the tongue; "the cat lapped up the milk"; "the cub licked the milk from its mother's breast"
dig_in: Occupy a trench or secured area; "the troops dug in for the night"
remain: Stay behind; "the smell stayed in the room"; "the hostility remained long after they made up"
regale: Provide with choice or abundant food or drink; "don't worry about the expensive wine--i'm treating"; "she treated her houseguests with good food every night"
cater: Give what is desired or needed, especially support, food or sustenance; "the hostess provided lunch for all the guests"
follow: Follow, discover, or ascertain the course of development of something; "we must follow closely the economic development is cuba"; "trace the student's progress"; "trace one's ancestry"
fulfil: Meet the requirements or expectations of
suckle: Suck milk from the mother's breasts; "the infant was suckling happily"
starve: Have a craving, appetite, or great desire for
famish: Be hungry; go without food; "let's eat--i'm starving!"
avoid: Stay clear from; keep away from; keep out of the way of someone or something; "her former friends now avoid her"
enjoy: Have for one's benefit; "the industry enjoyed a boom"
afford: Have the financial means to do something or buy something; "we can't afford to send our children to college"; "can you afford this car?"
englut: Overeat or eat immodestly; make a pig of oneself; "she stuffed herself at the dinner"; "the kids binged on ice cream"
quell: Suppress or crush completely; "squelch any sign of dissent"; "quench a rebellion"
fatten: Make fat or plump; "we will plump out that poor starving child"
inject: To insert between other elements; "she interjected clever remarks"
degust: Taste with relish; "degust this wonderful soup"
desist: Choose not to consume; "i abstain from alcohol"
revert: Go back to a previous state; "we reverted to the old rules"
sop_up: Take in, also metaphorically; "the sponge absorbs water well"; "she drew strength from the minister's words"
inhale: Draw in (air); "inhale deeply"; "inhale the fresh mountain air"; "the patient has trouble inspiring"; "the lung cancer patient cannot inspire air very well"
quench: Suppress or crush completely; "squelch any sign of dissent"; "quench a rebellion"
allay: Lessen the intensity of or calm; "the news eased my conscience"; "still the fears"
adjoin: Attach or add; "i adjoin a copy of your my lawyer's letter"
strew: Spread by scattering ("straw" is archaic); "strew toys all over the carpet"
dandle: Move (a baby) up and down in one's arms or on one's knees
seize: Affect; "fear seized the prisoners"; "the patient was seized with unbearable pains"; "he was seized with a dreadful disease"
nab: Tag the base runner to get him out
wrest: Obtain by seizing forcibly or violently, also metaphorically; "wrest the knife from his hands"; "wrest a meaning from the old text"; "wrest power from the old government"
calve: Give birth to (a calf); "the whales calve at this time of year"
cleave: Make by cutting into; "the water is going to cleave a channel into the rock"

wield: Have and exercise; "wield power and authority"
manage: Succeed in doing, achieving, or producing (something) with the limited or inadequate means available; "we got by on just a gallon of gas"; "they made do on half a loaf of bread every day"
fondle: Touch or stroke lightly in a loving or endearing manner; "he caressed her face"; "they fondled in the back seat of the taxi"
alter: Remove the ovaries of; "is your cat spayed?"
vary: Make something more diverse and varied; "vary the menu"
imbue: Fill, soak, or imbue totally; "soak the bandage with disinfectant"
incite: Provoke or stir up; "incite a riot"; "set off great unrest among the people"
egg_on: Urge on; cause to act; "the other children egged the boy on, but he did not want to throw the stone through the window"
knead: Make uniform; "knead dough"; "work the clay until it is soft"
bury: Dismiss from the mind; stop remembering; "i tried to bury these unpleasant memories"
spang: Leap, jerk, bang; "bullets spanged into the trees"
whet: Make keen or more acute; "whet my appetite"
smutch: Make a smudge on; soil by smudging
grow: Come to have or undergo a change of (physical features and attributes); "he grew a beard"; "the patient developed abdominal pains"; "i got funny spots all over my body"; "well-developed breasts"
resect: Surgically remove a part of a structure or an organ
carve: Engrave or cut by chipping away at a surface; "carve one's name into the bark"
modify: Add a modifier to a constituent
knap: Strike sharply; "rap him on the knuckles"
hew: Make or shape as with an axe; "hew out a path in the rock"
pare: Decrease gradually or bit by bit
elute: Wash out with a solvent, as in chromatography
reline: Put new lines on; "reline the paper"
reface: Put a new facing on (a garment)
bespot: Mark with, or as if with, spots
loosen: Make loose or looser; "loosen the tension on a rope"
nock: Make small marks into the surface of; "score the clay before firing it"
rumple: Become wrinkled or crumpled or creased; "this fabric won't wrinkle"
deform: Become misshapen; "the sidewalk deformed during the earthquake"
unbend: Make less taut; "relax the tension on the rope"

pice: A small copper coin of the East Indies, worth less than a cent
unfile: To remove from a file or record
aport: On or towards the port or left side; -- said of the helm
sweal: To melt and run down, as the tallow of a candle; to waste away without feeding the flame
cruset: A goldsmith's crucible or melting pot
adonai: A Hebrew name for God, usually translated in the Old Testament by the word "Lord"
vineal: Of or pertaining to vines; containing vines
whaap: (a) The European curlew; -- called also awp, whaup, great whaup, and stock whaup
eriach: A recompense formerly given by a murderer to the relatives of the murdered person
anisic: Of or derived from anise; as, anisic acid; anisic alcohol
shoer: One who fits shoes to the feet; one who furnishes or puts on shoes; as, a shoer of horses
faham: The leaves of an orchid (Angraecum fragrans), of the islands of Bourbon and Mauritius, used (in France) as a substitute for Chinese tea
cantar: A weight used in southern Europe and East for heavy articles
dromon: In the Middle Ages, a large, fast-sailing galley, or cutter; a large, swift war vessel
tinman: A manufacturer of tin vessels; a dealer in tinware
attle: Rubbish or refuse consisting of broken rock containing little or no ore
chevet: The extreme end of the chancel or choir; properly the round or polygonal part
quinic: Pertaining to, derived from, or connected with, quinine and related compounds; specifically, designating a nonnitrogenous acid obtained from cinchona bark, coffee, beans, etc
